intro: Puya novarae, commonly known as the Andean torch, is a striking plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its tall, spire-like inflorescence that can reach up to 5 meters in height. The plant produces vibrant red or orange flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators. Puya novarae is adapted to grow in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in cool, humid climates. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
